case_vignette: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of a painless, nonpruritic skin lesion on her right thigh. She initially thought it was an insect bite, but it has slowly increased in size over the past weeks. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 0.8-cm hyperpigmented papule. When the skin lesion is squeezed, the surface retracts inwards. A photograph of the lesion is shown.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. The case vignette you provided doesn't mention anything about sun exposure or tanning bed use.

The vignette doesn't mention any changes with heat or cold.

No, just the one on my thigh.

I haven't tried any medication or topical treatments on it.

The vignette doesn't say anything about the border of the bump.

**Final Diagnosis:** Unable to diagnose without physical examination and biopsy.
